Ye who would smile at simple nature's child,</br>Whose world seems bounded by his forest wild;</br>At the first white ship, with amazement dumb,</br>Musing from whence the prodigy should come;</br>Thrown up from Ocean's yet unfathom'd store?</br>Or dropp'd from heaven upon th' unwonted shore?</br>Smile too at deep philosophy, at pause,</br>Baffled, and overtask'd to trace the cause,</br>Whence all these wondrous changes had their birth,</br>In one short aera — one small nook of earth.</br>Smile at state prophecy, whose broadest light</br>Could never paint a vision, half so bright;</br>And smile at history, toiling at her scroll,</br>In vain, to note the changes as they roll.

There was, a time, and that within the span</br>Of the brief memory of short-liv'd man,</br>When, close confined along th' Atlantic seas,</br>The timid settler heard the western breeze,</br>And shrunk, expectant of the savage dart,</br>Or whizzing arrow, at his beating heart.</br>The western Mountains stood in awful forms,</br>Like clouds surcharg'd with tempest, fire and storms,</br>Whence the red bolt of rapid death might fly,</br>And whirlwinds rend the ocean and the sky;</br>For there did lurk the white-man's deadliest foe,</br>Gathering to burst upon the vales below.</br>A solemn race — a dark relentless clan,</br>That own'd no ties of blood with civil man;</br>A fearful foe — combining human art,</br>The wiles of serpents, and the tiger's heart:</br>Their sternest joy to daunt and scourge a race,</br>Softened by love — refined by Christian grace;</br>In tangled dells, where not heaven's light had shin'd,</br>They held there home — apt emblem of their mind.

Here many a bounteous stream majestic pours,</br>From distant mountains, to the ocean shores,</br>And in their course, enrich the earth in vain—</br>All unexplored, or hill, or vale, or plain,</br>And he was passing bold, who dared advance</br>Up toward their source, or e'en a thought to glance.</br>The soil was held by unresisted might,</br>The tiger's and the wolf's prescriptive right;</br>Nay e'en more awful images might wake—</br>Thick swarming skiffs along the stream and lake,</br>With desp'rate skill against the rapids glide,</br>Or down the cataract's tumultuous tide;</br>And hark!  the warwhoop o'er the valley floats;—</br>The wolf's wild howls are music's softest notes.

But light at length prevails; darkness retreats,</br>To fix, in distant dens, her gloomy seats:</br>Improving nature, at this long delay</br>Indignant, from her barriers bursts away,</br>Shakes off the savage forms, by which oppress'd</br>She languish'd long, and with new charms is dress'd.</br>The dark, cold tribes, less boldly urge the strife,</br>And melt before the light of civil life:</br>And gathering courage now, th' heroic swain,</br>Pursues them far toward the western main;</br>Nor yet the flight, nor the pursuit gives o'er,</br>Until their strength and terrors are no more:</br>Then turns to peaceful homes, and bright'ning plains,</br>Where life to long-protracted age remains.</br>The yeomen still survive, whose eye can trace</br>Successive changes on out country's face:</br>Where forests frown'd are shining cities seen,</br>And fields with Eden's bounty smile serene:</br>And many a soldier lives to tell the tales</br>Of deadly strife, mid yonder hills and vales;</br>Can point the spot where raging battle stood,</br>The very turf that drank his father's blood;</br>Can show the lake or stream where brothers bled,</br>Whose bones, scarce whiten'd, pave their lowly bed.</br>Perhaps some hero lives, who led the brave,</br>To freedom's boon, or honor's hallow'd grave;</br>His locks scarce changed — scarce lost, their raven hue:</br>Still firm in, strength — in thought and memory true;</br>Come Fancy!  come!  the image fair portray</br>Of some firm vet'ran bending back his way</br>To yonder fields, the arena of his strife,</br>For home and country, liberty and life.

Bright in his memory is the open glade,</br>Remotest trace that industry had made;</br>And fresh the image of the forest fierce,</br>Deep tangled, not meridian suns could pierce,</br>Where the grim savage, turning from his prey,</br>Slunk, like the wolf, and shun'd the face of day.</br>Onward the veteran moves; but where's that lawn,</br>Once the last line that civil man had drawn?</br>And where that wild wood rising dark and high,</br>Like strong embattled fortress to the sky!</br>Lo!  ether fields in endless prospect rise,</br>And like th' horizon, still the forest flies.</br>Yet sure 'twas here opposing armies stood;</br>That is the stream that reddened with his blood;</br>It was from thence the wild man's warwhoop rose,</br>And here he stemm'd the onset of the foes;</br>But lo!  the plain, hill, valley, all around,</br>With the bright POP'LOUS VILLAGE now are crown'd.</br>There, where the Indian often earth'd the wolf,</br>Along the brink of yonder tumbling gulph,</br>The rocks have yielded to the workman's hand,</br>And there in splendid palaces they stand.</br>Where the brisk waterfall, whose music found</br>No ear but echo once, to catch the sound,</br>Now, all its aid to human arts applied,</br>Prepares our food, and dress, and wealth beside;</br>See wheels on wheels, in mystic motion there!</br>The rattling engines of Minerva's care.

On yonder well-remember'd rising ground,</br>Where tallest firs with deepest shadows frown'd,</br>There now the noble Church sends up her spire,</br>To catch day's latest, and his earliest fire.</br>There, where the solitary wigwam stood,</br>Uncouthly form'd of stakes and leaves and mud,</br>Whose door stood wide, because it could not close,</br>To welcome weary wild men to repose;</br>Or mid the clouds of smoke and filth, to share</br>The half-seeth'd members of the savage bear;</br>There now the stately Inn, a spacious seat,</br>Invites the weary to refined retreat.</br>Around where ignorance had tak'n her stand,</br>With reign primeval, o'er the darken'd land,</br>See Learning's nurseries at ev'ry turn,</br>Where every urchin finds the means to learn;</br>And onward, see the high school's spacious halls,</br>And onward still, the prouder College walls.</br>Here bustling Trade is laden with his bales;</br>There Commerce spreads her wings, unfurls her sails;</br>Here on canals, deep freighted barges toil;</br>There groaning wains with products of the soil;</br>The thronging streets what busy numbers fill!</br>What tides of passengers roll onward still!</br>Not fled from want, but drawn by interest's bond</br>To visit peopled regions far beyond.</br>There, where the guard-house frown'd upon yon height</br>And weary sentinels wore out the night</br>With painful vigils, on their loaded arms,</br>To save the sleeping hamlet from alarms;</br>There now the green-house, shaded with the vine</br>And summer flowers, with evergreens entwine.</br>The terrors of the wilderness are fled,</br>And Niagara's thunders lost their dread;</br>Down its deep chasm, no hazard of his life,</br>Goes the soft cit, and e'en his softer wife.</br>And Huron's shadowy shore lights up its brow,</br>And wild Oswego does but tinkle now,</br>Whose very name but sounded, once would dart</br>A nervous terror through a foreign heart.</br>All these are fled, and peace and plenty reign</br>O'er rising town, and cultivated plain.

And say what subtle causes, passing strange,</br>Have in short period, wrought this mighty change?</br>Ask not Philosophy to find the clue,</br>For she will doubt, or swear it is not true;</br>Nor over History's dark annals pore,</br>For she records no parallel before.</br>But make your common sense, and nought beside,</br>Plain, unsophisticated sense, your guide.</br>Look on this generous soil, producing bread,</br>That even surplus millions might be fed:</br>See here no want, to stint the human frame,</br>Nor toils excessive, to impair the same;</br>No straitened bounds, no stifled city's breath</br>To breed contagion, and engender death;</br>No feudal lords, to act the tyrant's part,</br>Nor cringing vassalage, to blight the heart;</br>No proud oppressor, visiting your door,</br>To pluck from industry her well earn'd store;</br>No bribery, to evade those righteous laws,</br>That touch the poor man's as the rich man's cause:</br>No border warriors, pouncing on their prey,</br>Transport your wealth and children far away;</br>But unbarr'd gates and doors will safely keep</br>Your golden treasures, and your children's sleep.</br>Trace here the cause, for verily you can,</br>The magic art, of multiplying man.</br>When Europe's sons, from their precarious seats</br>Had ris'n, and sought for more secure retreats,</br>Hope pointed hither, as the promised shore—</br>Hither the tides of emigration pour.</br>The lab'rer loathed that masters of the soil</br>Should hold the total profit of his toil,</br>Fled to the spot, where freedom's base was laid,</br>Dress'd his own vine, and sat beneath its shade.</br>From legal plunder, too, the rich man came,</br>To save some remnant from the STATE'S fell claim;</br>The poor man rose, and followed to the land,</br>Where full supplies reward the feeblest hand</br>Or where at least, when deep misfortunes meet,</br>The wholesome laws provide secure retreat.</br>The humblest souls that e'er on heaven called,</br>Here sought the freedom which was there enthral'd,</br>Built up their altars as their conscience bade,</br>And found no Church, nor Tyrant to invade.</br>This happiness once tasted, now they find</br>No yearnings for the countries left behind;</br>But kindred souls and blood are won, t' increase</br>Their swelling numbers, and partake their peace.

Hail happy Village!  favourite of the west!</br>In thee our fond affections find their rest—</br>In thee the bright reality, that seemed</br>A phantom, tho' divinest Plato dreamed.</br>We see the basis, broad, and deeps and sure,</br>On which thy happiness may rest secure:</br>The government which equal laws restrain,</br>And no caprice can mingle with their reign:</br>Laws, that on nature and on reason rest,</br>Long tried, and sanctioned by Religion's test:</br>The wholesome customs, awed by fear divine</br>The decent manners, which the whole refine:</br>Plenty so full, that theft forgets to steal,</br>And lawless plunder can no motives feel;</br>And conscious peace, distending every breast,</br>Redoubled all, that neighbours too are blest;</br>And squalid want, emaciated care,</br>And wandering beggary are unknown there.</br>We ask not where thy happiness is found,</br>'Tis full and free, pervading all around.

There stands the INN — a lodge where Kings might rest;</br>And oft some exil'd King has been its guest;</br>Where wandering princes luxury might find,</br>Nor miss the Villas that they left behind.</br>There journeying merchants, yeomen of the soil,</br>And learned trav'lers oft relax their toil;</br>The rattling wheels bring in, at ev'ning time,</br>The tide of guests from ev'ry state and clime:</br>Rous'd by the porter, at the early dawn,</br>Refresh'd by sleep, again the tide rolls on.</br>No bloated landlord meets you at the door,</br>Whose rank excess steams forth at ev'ry pore;</br>No sooty bar-room there, on every side</br>With broken chairs and two-legg'd stools supplied;</br>Whose narrow windows but exclude the day,</br>If yet through cobwebs it might find its way;</br>Whose wainscot, from the ceiling to the floor,</br>With "strayed or stolen," or "stop thief," stuck o'er;</br>But splendid drawing rooms, with carpets strown,</br>And seats and sofas like the softest down.</br>The spacious halls where rich repasts are spread:</br>The dormitories, for each guest a bed;</br>The open walk — the cover'd colonnade,—</br>As cold or heat demands the sun or shade;</br>The parlor, where the harpsichord is found,</br>Soft-breathing flutes, or organ's nobler sound.</br>Cast o'er the guests your scrutinizing view—</br>No lounging, drinking, wrangling, bedlam's crew,</br>Where the stale song with witless toasts is crown'd,</br>And the loud horse-laugh and the slap goes round;</br>But minds well furnished, with experience fraught,</br>On high eventful times exchanging thought;</br>And sure the circling sun sees, from the skies,</br>No spot where themes of higher moment rise—</br>A people's glory risen — and rising yet,—</br>No splendor waning — and no glory set.

The village School — that scene of constant joy,</br>Where little pleasures flow and never cloy;</br>Where e'en the truant's current briskly flows,</br>Too strong and light for rods or tasks t' oppose.</br>The village school — an image fair and bright,</br>Welcom'd and wing'd with every new delight!</br>Life's starting goal — the struggle scarce begun—</br>While yet no race is lost, nor race is won—</br>Back to that source we trace the gilded show</br>In which the wealthy cit delights to glow;</br>For when a tyro, mid his fellows there,</br>He hoarded pins with unexampled care;</br>So the light insect that outshines the day,</br>Within the microscopic nit once lay.</br>Thither we trace the Statesman's lofty fame,</br>That Senates fear, and Nations joy to claim;</br>There first his lisping eloquence began,</br>There first he pleaded for the rights of man.</br>So the proud stream that swells the ocean's tide,</br>Flows from some trickling spring a leaf might bide.</br>The hero's bravery, at whose name and voice</br>Ten thousand firesides tremble or rejoice,</br>There felt its earliest glowings, to defend,</br>From petit tyranny, some injured friend.</br>So the strong fleet, that thunders round the earth,</br>From the nut's embryo bursted into birth.

The times are fled — and pedantry no more</br>Can pass for learning — dust for precious ore;</br>For rustic ignorance no more is found</br>To stand amaz'd at "words of thundering sound;"</br>And pedants fly the scene, nor longer dare,</br>With show of science, and with mystic air,</br>To teach in puzzles, what, if 'twere but true,</br>Is hid from pupil, and from master too.</br>See now the village master, in whose mind</br>The light of science has aris'n and shined;</br>Who leads the open faculties of youth,</br>By plain, direct, and easy paths, to truth.</br>The trust is sacred, pedants!  court it not,</br>Lest your false race should never be forgot.</br>Momentous trust to nurture and to bring</br>A Nation's glory from the budding spring.</br>Ah!  pamper'd, literary pride, avaunt!</br>Who, at those College Halls, would point the taunt;</br>Because, forsooth, his infancy was press'd</br>And fondled at some elder sister's breast.</br>Those recent walls will wipe away the crime</br>Of being new — do but allow them time.</br>What if, for want of nutritive supply,</br>Her sons, too early weaned, must haply hie</br>To life's broad common, and graze up their fare,</br>So sown with thorns — so bleak with chilling air?</br>Nay, what if ALMA MATER'S empty hands</br>Can send no favorite sons to foreign lands,</br>To seek fair Science, where she holds her court;</br>To gather arts where all the arts resort;</br>The Alps or Pyranees to clamber o'er,</br>Or carve their names on Padua's ancient door;</br>To ask the latest fashion of the faith,</br>Where creeds are form'd at each caprice's breath;</br>Then, like the laden bees, return once more,</br>T' enrich their country with their honeyed store?</br>Fond ALMA MATER!  what if nought beside</br>Some sidelong glance of love, thou canst provide</br>For e'en thy favorite sons?  yet why despair?</br>They hold the common earth, and common air:</br>And times may change, for change now rules the hour,</br>And sheds around the influence other power,</br>That e'en this plain reality exceeds</br>Creative fancy's wildest, noblest deeds;</br>And soon Mecaenases may rise, and shed</br>Their golden bounty over Learning's head.

Now to the decent Church our thoughts return,</br>Whither our willing feet have often borne,</br>When solemn themes mov'd our vibrating strings,</br>And hope was pregnant with immortal things.</br>'Tis not alone, that village prospects round,</br>Are fill'd and finish'd by that spire — and crown'd:</br>'Tis not alone the evidence that prayer,</br>And meek devotion, do not languish there;</br>A thousand prouder monuments may stand</br>Of wrested tithes from patient labour's hand;</br>Yet, with abated pleasure, freemen see</br>The loftiest piles, where not the heart is free;</br>'Tis this that clothes thy fabric with its charms,</br>The free-will offering — shed from bounty's arms.</br>In gilded domes proud prelates may be found,</br>To cheat the hungering soul, with unknown sound;</br>But nought can win us, or delights impart,</br>Save truth's free breast, and language of the heart.</br>In native dignity, thy preacher stands,</br>More than the dignity of robes and bands;</br>Nor needs a surplice to convince your mind</br>His head can teach, his life can lead mankind:</br>Nor seeks a sacred office he, to hide</br>An infidel's false heart, or worldling's pride;</br>Nor shows the crackling flames of fiery zeal,</br>The bigot's selfish feelings to conceal.</br>On superstition's aid he rests no claim,</br>To wake devotion, or increase its flame;</br>One word of wisdom awes with truer grace</br>Than Endor's dame, with all her sickly race.</br>No prude, to rail at fashions of the times,</br>And pick at peccadillos — while the crimes</br>That strike within, and deepest stains impart,</br>And damn the soul, scarce shock his tender heart:</br>No tyrant he, to rule the church with fear,</br>Nor lean upon her strength, to domineer:</br>When meek persuasion's force is fruitless seen,</br>His duty is discharg'd, his hands are clean.</br>His form and mien no sensualist betray,</br>Whose body o'er his soul usurps the sway;</br>Whose fair, smooth brow, and florid cheek declare,</br>No cure of souls, no love of learning there;</br>But comely paleness decent leanness, shew</br>The scholar's patience, and the pastor's too—</br>To him philosophy's best light has shined,</br>Not to bewilder and mislead his mind,</br>Not his warm love to chill, or to recall</br>From that High King "who ruleth over all,"</br>Nor plunge in Nature's causes, and refine,</br>To miss the traces of the hand Divine;</br>To push him on to doubt, and dark despair,</br>To feed his lambs with nature's stinted fare;</br>Tho' wise in nature, he on grace relies,</br>To lead his flock, and win them to the skies.

The heart's own bitterness — those secret woes,</br>That ask some genial bosom for repose—</br>There all within the faithful Pastor's breast,</br>Or private thoughts, or secret woes, may rest.</br>And when some stern calamity has riven</br>The sweetest ties of life that God has given,</br>Behold him then, still faithful to his trust,</br>Beside the mourner, sitting in the dust.</br>With cheerful face he meets each tender youth,</br>And drops upon his heart some welcome truth:</br>He cheers the aged onward, since the prize</br>Of immortality the nearer lies.</br>O'er bright prosperity, and fair success,</br>'Tis his pure joy, to lift the hand and bless;</br>Nor on life's comforts with disdain looks down,</br>Nor flies its pleasures with an anchoret's frown;</br>His presence oft to sparkling wit gives birth,</br>And brightens social life with chastened mirth:</br>The steadfast friend, when joy and plenty crown;</br>And still the friend, when want and sorrow frown.</br>He binds no burdens that he will not bear—</br>Prescribes no sacrifice he will not share;</br>The bright example of each precept given,</br>He rather leads, than points the way to heaven.</br>O!  when is rural happiness complete?</br>'Tis when the pious flock and preacher meet,</br>On sacred seasons, void of earthly care,</br>And pour devotion, in the house of prayer.

But see!  above, and onward, and around,</br>What scenes of village pleasure still abound!</br>The open hill, the wood beyond the glade,</br>The broken chasm the trickling brook has made:</br>There youth and age, and friends and lovers stray,</br>When o'er the scene the earliest zephyrs play.</br>The seats of living rock, the shady bower,</br>For summer's noon, or evening's balmy hour;</br>The boughs of Autumn, with their fruits o'erborne;</br>The golden promise of the ripening corn;</br>The thousand pleasures that relieve the night,</br>When winter suns too soon withdraw their light;</br>The youthful bands, with rural relish still,</br>Glide like the arrow down the ice-clad hill:</br>Their graver sires, who deeper interests feel,</br>In councils sitting, on the public weal;</br>Th' assembly's hall, where polished wit beguiles,</br>Or festive innocence presides and smiles;</br>The long processions o'er the frozen lakes,</br>And the light joy that winter's music wakes.</br>How have we seen the purest of delight,</br>Kindle and spread on many a bridal night!</br>Amidst the gay-dress'd group, the happy pair,</br>Smiled on by eager swain, and blushing fair;</br>The bridegroom, joyful that this day has come—</br>The bride still pressed with lingering thoughts of home—</br>Parental cares, so oft foreboding ill—</br>Parental hopes that bids those fears be still;</br>E'en wrinkled brows with smiles unwonted shine,</br>As in the sports of youth the grandsires join;</br>The reverend pastors fondly bent to call</br>Heaven's choicest blessings on his children all;</br>His hand not much conversant with the gold,</br>That children of this world intensely hold;</br>Pardon'd the more, if now his heart might be</br>Some trifle lighter for the marriage fee.

Hail!  sweetest village!  favourite of the west!</br>Again we hail thee, and pronounce thee blest.</br>Those vices foul that crowded cities fret,</br>Like leper's spots, have never reached thee yet.</br>No rising mobs within thy streets appear—</br>No bagnio's riot there salutes the ear:</br>Not the deep plans that bankrupts still contrive,</br>To cheat by law, as merchants fail and thrive.</br>Yet haply, too, some petit village pride</br>May mar thy peace, or ruffle its smooth tide:—</br>The village Miss, in lappets, gay display'd,</br>Looks scornful on the homelier hamlet maid;</br>Proud of the spire with which your church is crown'd;</br>Proud of the clock that tells the hours around;</br>Proud of your public buildings, walks, and squares;</br>Proud of your bustling market days and fairs;</br>Proud (and though vainer far than all beside,)</br>E'en of your Parson, cherishing your pride;</br>For oft he borrows from your vain conceit</br>Talents that ne'er in human bosoms meet.</br>And haply too, some competitions rise:—</br>Aspiring neighbours glance with jealous eyes;</br>Some rival sect, with zeal's ephemeral fire,</br>Plants on the neighouring hill its rival spire;</br>Some shame-faced scandal, creeping in the dark,</br>Some embryo malice, dying in the spark;</br>No more:  Those bitter gibes that oft provoke,</br>In prouder cities, the assassin's stroke,</br>And that false honor, tainted by a breath,</br>Leaping to desperation and to death,</br>Deform thee not; and if not spotless thou,</br>So heaven's bright orb has spots upon his brow.

Canst thou be happy, since midst thy throng</br>No nobles trail their retinue along?</br>Nor through thy streets the livened heralds fly,</br>And shout "his Majesty is coming by?"</br>Nor e'en the Peers', nor the Lord Mayor's suites,</br>Are dragg'd by slavish men along thy streets?</br>Nor demagogue, whose name a moment floats,</br>While yet his whiskey lasts, to buy your votes?</br>Nor manor broad, nor overgrown estate,</br>Nor princely castle, with its massy gate?</br>No formal feasts — no luxury refined—</br>Nor yet affected softness of the mind?</br>No hours of fashion that elude the light,</br>And turn the night to days and day to night?</br>Nor yet those Sunday feastings that desert</br>The church, and break an honest Pastor's heart?</br>Yes, thou art blest!  nor needest these false shows,</br>To gild corruption o'er, and hide thy woes.</br>And long may'st thou survive, and scape the bane</br>And snares and dangers that have others slain;</br>The rage of party, and ambition high,</br>Plethoric numbers, and rank luxury:</br>No earthquake shake thee from thy peaceful seat!</br>No ruptured mount o'erwhelm thee at his feet!</br>No stream, with altered courses, sweep thee far!</br>No Goths nor Vandals bring the torch of war!</br>Far be the time, if e'er high Heaven's decree</br>Shall yet award the fate of all to thee,</br>When all thy bright inhabitants shall die</br>And pil'd within thy cemeteries lie:</br>And happy fathers, long thy hope and guide,</br>And virtuous matrons, still thy boast and pride.</br>And sons, to copy those who go before,</br>And daughters seen in thee no more — no more!</br>Ne'er be the time, when o'er thy grassy bed</br>The pilgrim strangers shall inquiring tread,</br>And trace thee only by the crumbling bones,</br>The mound of earth, or the unletter'd stones;</br>As those dark millions unrecorded died,</br>Who sleep along the deep Missouri's side;</br>No!  thou hast lived in light, and still shalt live</br>That life that history's deathless page can give.</br>Then flourish fair, whilst heaven allots this part,</br>For thou hast pleasures to enchant the heart;</br>Thine are the pure delights, the solid charms,</br>That hold thy children fast within thine arms,</br>Attract the wanderer from the ocean side,</br>And many a pilgrim o'er th' Atlantic tide;</br>Whom timid friends on foreign shores would keep,</br>Or frighten back, with dangers of the deep,</br>With fancied images of savage men,</br>The rattling serpent, and the tiger's den.</br>And yet, once tasted, who thy sweets would spurn?</br>And who returns, or wishes to return?</br>From feudal lands are rural pleasure fled?</br>Are villages, once bright, decay'd and dead?</br>The busy population left the streets,</br>And, o'er the ocean, fixed in distant seats?</br>The walls o'erthrown, the well-set hedges broke,</br>The brooks, once bubbling, reeds and sedges choak?</br>Where now those people, there beheld no more?</br>Lo!  here — and busier — happier than before.

And thou, sweet POET!  who, in pensive strains,</br>Didst weep deserted AUBURN'S poor remains—</br>Mourn for the well-lov'd friends no longer found,</br>And wide-spread desolation all around;</br>Where thou hadst hoped that life's concluding day</br>Should gently fade, like summer's parting ray;</br>Lo!  here thy restless spirit, hovering o'er,</br>May find the AUBURN that was lost before.</br>Hail, happy bard!  thrice happy in thy theme;</br>For lamentations well the song beseem;</br>Whilst I, ill-fated bard, must toil, and sing</br>Such themes as thriving trade and business bring;</br>And strengthening walls, and the swift rattling wheels,</br>Smooth brow'd content, and laughter's loudest peals;</br>And wealth, reclining on her well-fill'd store;</br>And high repletion, that demands no more:</br>Such themes as scarce to poesy belong—</br>Themes that confound the melting strains of song:</br>Then hail!  thou wandering spirit, and be blest!</br>Rest!  sainted Poet — bard anointed — rest!</br>
